topic.topicDesc: Perform basic operations with addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division
topic.info: Using Mathologica expressions can be entered and then easily simplified. The rules of order of operations always apply.

topic.topicDesc: Check if two expressions are equivalent.
topic.info: When there are two expressions that simplify to a numeric value, Mathologica can check to see if they are equal.

topic.topicDesc: Simplify, add, subtract, multiply, and divide fractions.
topic.info: Fractions can be added, subtracted, multiplied, or divided. Fractions in unreduced form can be reduced.

topic.topicDesc: Distribute numbers or variables when parentheses are used.
topic.info: Multiply each of the terms inside by the term being distributed.

topic.topicDesc: Collect like terms to simplify the expression.
topic.info: For like terms add the coefficients of the variable together.

topic.topicDesc: Solve linear equations in the form y=mx or y=x+b
topic.info: To obtain an answer you need to solve for the unknown. That means getting the 'x' (or whatever the letter is) isolated on the left hand side. These types of equations require only one type of operation to isolate the unknown.

topic.topicDesc: Solve linear equations in the form y=mx+b
topic.info: With these types of equations two steps will be required to get the variable isolated on the left hand side.

topic.topicDesc: Solve linear equations of any form.
topic.info: Solving these equations requires a combination of simplifying terms, dividing by coefficients, and moving terms to the other side.

topic.topicDesc: Solve equations involving ratios or proportions.
topic.info: When two things are related they can sometimes be described using ratios or proportions. Equations can then be set up to solve for the unknown.

topic.topicDesc: Graph linear equations on the xy plane.
topic.info: Linear functions in the form y=mx+b can be graphed.

topic.topicDesc: Graph multiple Functions at a time.
topic.info: Any number of functions can be graphed on the same xy plane at the same time. Simply use the add line button and enter the next equation on the new line.

topic.topicDesc: Solve system of equations using the substitution technique.
topic.info: To use the substitution technique in a system of equations solve for a variable then substitute that result into the next equation until a result has been obtained.

topic.topicDesc: Solve a system of equations using the elimination technique.
topic.info: To use this technique combine two equations together through addition or subtraction.

topic.topicDesc: Solve system of equations that have three variables.
topic.info: Use the techniques of substitution or elimination with system of equations that contain three variables.

topic.topicDesc: Use the properties of exponents to simplify expressions.
Multiply two binomials together giving a quadratic.
topic.info: Multiply two terms in the form `ax+b` together giving a quadratic in the form `ax^2+bx+c`. It is important to remember to use the technique of first, outside, inside, last (FOIL) here.

topic.topicDesc: Factor quadratics.
topic.info: This is the opposite of two binomials where starting at `ax^2+bx+c` the result of two binomials in the form `ax+b` is obtained.

topic.topicDesc: Solve quadratic equations.
topic.info: Solve equations in the form `ax^2+bx+c=0`. Two solutions are obtained from this. Not all quadratics are factorable.

topic.topicDesc: Solve quadratics using the technique of completing the square.
topic.info: Solve equations in the form `ax^2+bx+c=0`. All quadratics can be solved using the complete the square method.

topic.topicDesc: Solve quadratics with the quadratic equation.
topic.info: Solve equations in the form `ax^2+bx+c=0`. The quadratic equation is a generalized form of completing the square. The quadratic equation is `x=\frac{-b \pm \sqrt{b^2-4ac}}{2a}`.

topic.topicDesc: Find the vertex of a quadratic equation.
topic.info: The vertex of a quadratic equation in the form `ax^2+bx+c` is given by `\frac{-b}{2a}`. The equation is also symmetrical across the vertex.

topic.topicName: Find the Discriminant of a Quadratic
topic.topicDesc: Find the discriminant of a quadratic equation.
topic.info: The discriminant for an equation in the form `ax^2+bx+c` is given by `b^2-4ac`. If the discriminant is negative there will be no solutions to the quadratic, if it is zero there will be one, and if it is positive there will be two.

topic.topicDesc: Graph quadratic equations on the xy plane.
Get the domain of radical expression.
topic.info: The domain of a radical function must always be such that the inside of the radical is greater or equal to zero. A radical is anything with a fractional exponent (roots).

topic.topicDesc: Solve a radical equation for an unknown.
topic.info: Use exponents to cancel the radicals. Remember the radicals have fractional powers. Not all of these equations have solutions. A radical of any index can be used.

topic.topicDesc: Solve a radical equation for an unknown.
topic.info: Use exponents to cancel the radicals. Remember the radicals have fractional powers. Not all of these equations have solutions. These types of equations can involve radicals and other terms.

topic.topicDesc: Graph radical equation on the xy plane.
topic.info: Keep the domain of the expression in mind when graphing the function. For radical expressions the inside of even root can never be negative.

topic.topicDesc: Apply operations to groups of polynomials.
topic.info: Apply the principles of combining like terms to add and subtract polynomials.

topic.topicDesc: Solve linear inequalities.
topic.info: When solving linear inequalities a solution domain rather than a single solution is obtained.

topic.topicDesc: Solve quadratic inequalities.
topic.info: Solving quadratic inequalities produces a solution domain rather than a single solution.

topic.topicDesc: Solve inequalities containing non linear inequalities.
Solve compound inequalities.
topic.info: When solving compound inequalities each case must be solved for separately.

topic.topicDesc: Solve inequalities involving rational expressions.
Solve inequalites involving polynomials.
Use and simplify expressions involving imaginary numbers.
topic.info: The imaginary number `i` is defined as `i = \sqrt{-1}`.

topic.topicDesc: Perform operations on complex numbers.
topic.info: A complex number is a combination of a real and a complex number. To simplify complex number expressions the principles of imaginary numbers must be used.

topic.topicDesc: Equations that have complex solutions as answers.
Use DeMovire's Theorem to find all the roots of an equation.
Simplify rational expressions using canceling or factoring.
Solve rational equations.
Graph rational equations.
Multiply polynomials together.
Divide two polynomials.
Solve polynomial equations using factoring.
Evaluate logarithms.
Use the properties of logarithms to simplify expressions.
Find the domain of log functions
Solve equations with a single logarithm
Solve equations with multiple logarithms using the properties of logarithms
Solve equations where the variable is in the exponent.

topicName.topicDesc: Solve equations where the variable is in the exponent.

topic.topicDesc: Assign values to be used later.
Assign functions to be used later.
topic.info: With Mathologica assigning functions is easy. Just select the option 'Assign Function' under the evaluation drop down and the function will be saved for use at a later time. The function can even be used in the same input.

topic.topicDesc: After a function has been assigned it can be manipulated in a later expression.
Evaluate functions with a given input.
Find the domain of any function.
Compose functions where one function is the input to another function.
Transform functions.
Solve algebraic equations with u-substitution.
Use the Pythagorean theorem to find the unknown side of triangle.
Evaluate trigonometric functions in degrees.
Evaluate reciprocal trigonometric functions in degrees.
Evaluate trigonometric functions in radians.
Find the properties of trig functions such as the period and amplitude.
Find the domain of trig functions.
Graph trig functions.
Evaluate inverse trig functions.

topic.topicPath: Trigonometry/Inverse Trig Functions/Inverse Trig Function Domain
topic.topicDesc: Find the domain of inverse trig functions.
Solve basic trig equations.
Solve equations that involve trigonometric functions. Solving this equations will require simplifications first.
Use the permutation function.
Use the combination function.
Define and use parametric equations.
Convert complex numbers to exponential form
Convert complex numbers to polar form.
Evaluate limits that can be evaluate using basic simplifications. This can involve factoring to cancel terms or multiplying the top and bottom by the conjugate.
Evaluate limits of a wide variety of functions.
Evaluate limits that are undefined.
Take the limits of polynomials to infinity.

topic.topicName: Limits of Rational Expressions to Infinity
topic.topicDesc: Take the limits of rational expressions to infinity.

topic.topicName: Limits to Infinity of Special Functions
topic.topicDesc: Limits to infinity of various functions.
Use the limit definition of a derivative to find the derivative for functions.
Use the power rule to find the derivatives of polynomials.
Find the derivatives of trig functions.
Use the chain rule to find the derivatives of a composition of functions.
Take the derivative of an expression where the variable is in the exponent.
Take the derivative of an expression involving logarithms.
Use the chain rule on a composition of numerous functions.
Use the product rule to find the derivative of a product of two functions.
Use the quotient rule to find the derivative of the quotient of two functions.
Find the derivatives of reciprocal trig functions.
Calculate derivatives of terms of an implicit expression involving both the function and the variable.
Apply L'Hopital's Rule to solve limit problems.
Find the anti-derivatives of polynomials.
Find the anti-derivatives of trig functions.
Calculate definite integrals.
Calculate functions defined by the boundaries on a definite integral.
Evaluate integrals using u-substitution.
Evaluate integrals using integration by parts.
Evaluate improper integrals where the boundaries of the integral are to infinity.
Evaluate integrals using trig identities.
Find the arc length of a line using integration.
Use summations to add up all the elements of a sequence.
Check if a sequence diverges or converges when summed to infinity.
Compute the Maclaurin and Taylor series approximations for functions.
Add and subtract.
Normalize a vector.
Find the dot product of two vectors.
Take the cross product of two vectors.
Add and subtract matrices.
Multiply two matrices together.
Find the determinant of a matrix.
Transpose matrices.
Find the inverses of matrices.
Calculate double integrals.
Calculate triple integrals.
Take partial derivatives of functions.
Apply the gradient function to a scalar field.
Find the divergence of a vector field.
Find the curl of a vector field.
Use line integrals with scalar functions.
Take the derivatives of vector functions.

topic.topicPath: Advanced Calculus/Line Integrals with Vector Functions
topic.topicDesc: Use line integrals with vector functions.
Evaluate surface integrals.

exampleInput.input: f(x,y,z)=y; x(u,v)=u; y(u,v)=v; z(u,v)=u+v^2; 0 \lt u \lt 1; 0 \lt v \lt 2; \int\int_{\Sigma} f(x,y,z) d\sigma
f(x,y,z)=y; v(u,v)=u\vec{i}+v\vec{j}+(u+v^2)\vec{k}; 0 \lt u \lt 1; 0 \lt v \lt 2; \int\int_{\Sigma} f(x,y,z) d\sigma
